claim:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fatigue. He reports that during this time he has had occasional palpitations and shortness of breath. He has sickle cell disease. Current medications include hydroxyurea and folic acid. He appears fatigued. His temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Examination shows pale conjunctivae. Cardiac examination shows a midsystolic ejection murmur. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 6.4 g/dl
Leukocyte count 6,000/mm3
Platelet count 168,000/mm3
Mean corpuscular volume 84 μm3
Reticulocyte count 0.1%
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?" : Medication-induced hemolysis

supporting.text: The patient's low hemoglobin (6.4 g/dL) and low reticulocyte count (0.1%) suggest bone marrow suppression, which is a known side effect of hydroxyurea, a medication he is currently taking.

attacks.text: The patient's low hemoglobin (6.4 g/dL) and low reticulocyte count (0.1%) suggest bone marrow suppression, which is a known side effect of hydroxyurea, a medication he is currently taking.

The patient's fever (38.3°C) and tachycardia (pulse 120/min) are more indicative of an acute infection or vaso-occlusive crisis, common in sickle cell disease, rather than medication-induced bone marrow suppression.
Hydroxyurea typically causes macrocytosis (high MCV), but this patient's MCV is normal (84 μm3), making hydroxyurea-induced bone marrow suppression less likely.
While infection is possible, the absence of leukocytosis (WBC 6,000/mm3) and the profoundly low reticulocyte count strongly suggest bone marrow suppression rather than an acute infectious process.
The normal MCV could be due to concurrent iron deficiency or thalassemia trait, which can mask the macrocytosis expected with hydroxyurea use.

In sickle cell disease, acute chest syndrome or other vaso-occlusive events can cause fever and tachycardia without significant leukocytosis, maintaining the plausibility of an acute complication rather than medication effect.
